Effects of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 particles on properties of PVA/xylan composite films
Xinxin Liu, Xiaofeng Chen, Junli Ren ⁎, Minmin Chang, Bei He, Chunhui Zhang ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Pulp and Paper Engineering, School of Light Industry and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, Guangdong, China
⁎ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: renjunli@scut.edu.cn (J. Ren), chunh
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijbiomac.2019.03.088 0141-8130/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 21 November 2018 Received in revised form 12 March 2019 Accepted 13 March 2019 Available online 14 March 2019
The effects of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 on the properties of PVA/xylan composite films were investigated in this work. Results showed that nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 could effectively improve themechanical strength,moisture and oxygen barrier properties and surface hydrophobic property of the composite films. The results of FTIR and XRD indicated the interaction of hydrogen bonds between nanoparticles and PVA and xylan. When the contents of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 in the composite films were 3%, the tensile strength was increased to 20.4 MPa and 22.5 MPa, respectively, while water vapor permeability (3.14 and 3.03 × 10−11 g·m−1·s−1·Pa−1) and oxygen permeability (5.28 and 5.003 cm3·m−2·24 h−1·0.1 MPa−1) reached the minima. With the increase of nanoZnO and nano-SiO2 dosage, the solubility of composite films was increased. When the contents of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2were 3% and 4%, respectively, the contact angles of the filmswas increased up to 101° and 78°. Besides, the composite filmswith nano-ZnO exhibitedUV shielding performance, whereas the oneswith nano-SiO2 had similar UV light-transparency to the pure PVA/xylan composite films.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The film-forming properties of xylan were affected by its short molecular chain, low molecular weight, high glass transition temperature, and low solubility inwater [1,2]. However, intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonding can be formed between hydroxyl groups of xylan during the film formation process. Hydroxyl groups in the xylan molecule can also act as reactive sites with other polymers (chitosan, cellulose, lignin, and PVA), which expands the potential application of xylan in film materials. Chitosan/xylan composite films were prepared by immersion of a chitosan film in the xylan solution [3]. Introduction of xylan into chitosan films resulted in a higher crystallinity and a more compact structure, and greatly improved the tensile strength, breaking elongation and antiultraviolet performance of chitosan/xylan films. Goksu and his co-workers [4] studied the effects of cotton xylan on the performance of lignin/xylan composite films. Results showed that the elongation at break (45% to 57%) and the flexibility of the compositefilmwere significantly improved, and theWVP (water vapor permeability) value was reduced. Gao and his co-workers [5] studied the effects of 1,2,3,4-butanetetracarboxylic acid (BTCA) on the properties of PVA/xylan composite films. The elongation at break and tensile strength of composite films reached maxima of 92.4% and 22.4MPa, respectively, when the content of BTCA was 20 w%.
ui@scut.edu.cn (C. Zhang).
Filmmaterials prepared by combing organic polymers and inorganic particles usually have better properties than those of organic films [6]. Inorganic particles in the composite films can modify the hydrophilic– lipophilic balance and impart unique properties to the composite films [7]. In our previous study, the effects of nano-TiO2 on the performance of PVA/xylan composite films were investigated [8]. Results showed that nano-TiO2 could improve the mechanical strength, moisture impermeability, UV shielding performance and oxygen barrier properties of the composite film.
ZnO is generally recognized as a safematerial. The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has confirmed its resistance to foodborne pathogens and spoilage bacteria [9,10]. As a multifunctional inorganic metal oxide, nano-ZnO has unique properties, such as physical and chemical stability, photocatalytic activity, ultraviolet and infrared absorption, antibacterial ability and non-toxicity [11]. Thus, nano-ZnO has been used in various applications, such as food packaging [10,12,13], cosmetics [14], medicine [15], dye degradation [16], optical devices [17] and biosensors [18]. Various amounts of nanoclay montmorillonite (MMT) and ZnO nanopowders were used to analyze the properties of biodegradable nanocomposites of cationic starch (CS) [19].The water vapor permeability and the UV light transmittance of the nanocomposites reduced after the contents of MMT and ZnO increased, tensile strength (TS) of nanocomposites increased after the incorporation of ZnO and MMT nanoparticles although the elongation at break was diminished. Tapiocastarch/gelatin/nanorod ZnO (ZnO-N) bionanocomposites were prepared via solution casting technique [20]. The tensile strength of thefilmswas increased from14 to 18MPawhereas elongation at breaks
decreased from 18 to 8% and oxygen permeability decreased from 151.03 to 91.52 cm3μm/(m2–day) by incorporation of 3.5% ZnO-N into biopolymer matrix. Besides, amorphous nano-SiO2 also has other advantages such as high specific surface area, stability, durability and thermal stability [21,22]. Unlike the carcinogenicity of crystalline SiO2 [23], amorphous SiO2 is a stable and safe food additive that has been widely used in food processing and preservation [24,25]. The effects of nanosilicon dioxide (nano-SiO2) and the ratio of PVA/gelatin (1:1 and 2:1) on the physicochemical and structural properties of gelatin/polyvinyl alcohol composite films were investigated [26]. The results showed that the highest value of tensile strength (18.05 MPa) was found for a PVA/gelatin ratio of 2:1 and 1% nano-SiO2 (P2:G1-1%).
In summary, the introduction of nanoparticles could improve the tensile strength of composites films. However, the strength of the composite films in the above references could be further improved by our method. The dispersion of nanoparticles affected the mechanical strength of composite films, the more uniform the dispersion of nanoparticles, the better the effect on the mechanical strength of the composite films. In our previous study [8], the nano-TiO2 could be well dispersed in sodium hexametaphosphate (SHMP) solution, therefore the SHMP solution was selected as the solvent instead of water in this experiment. Based on the unique properties of nanoparticles and the potential application of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 in food packaging and storage, a series of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 enhanced PVA/xylan composite films were prepared. The effects of those nanoparticles on the mechanical properties, water vapor and oxygen barrier properties, thermal stability and UV shielding properties were investigated in this paper.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Beech wood xylan (Mw of 130, 000 g·mol−1) and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, Mw of 146, 000-186, 000 g·mol−1) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich (Karlsruhe, Germany). Nano-zinc oxide (ZnO), nano-silica (SiO2) and sodium hexametaphosphate (SHMP, 99%) were obtained from Macklin Reagent Company Limited (Shanghai, China). Lithium chloride (LiCl) and potassium nitrate (KNO3) were obtained from Ke Miou reagent Company Limited (Tianjin China). Glycerol was purchased from Guanghua Chemical Company Limited (Guangzhou, China). Deionized water was used for preparation of the composite films. All materials were of analytical-reagent grade and used without further purification.
2.2. Preparation of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 enhanced PVA/xylan composite films
PVA/xylan composite films were prepared by ultrasonic dispersion and solution casting. PVA was dissolved in 50 mL of 0.04% SHMP by
Scheme 1. The synthesis proce
heating to 95 °C. After cooling down to 80 °C, xylan and glycerol (10%, based on the total weight of PVA and xylan) were added. The effect of glycerol was to improve the compatibility of PVA/xylan. The weight ratio of PVA to xylan was 3. Nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 (0–4% weight ratio, based on the total weight of PVA and xylan) were dispersed in 50 mL of 0.04% SHMP solution respectively and stirred for 30 min, then sonified for another 30 min under the room temperature. The nano-particle dispersion was gradually dropped into the PVA/xylan solution under stirring. After ultrasonic defoaming treatment, the above mixture was poured onto a PTFE mould and dried in an oven at 40 °C, and the resulting composite films were obtained. All the films were kept at 23 °C with 50% relative humidity (RH) for at least 48 h prior to measurements. The composite films were named Z0, Z1, Z2, Z3, Z4 and S0, S1, S2, S3, S4 according to the dosage of nanoparticles (0–4%). The synthesis process of the composite filmswas proposed in Scheme1.
2.3. Characterization of composite films
The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectrum of composite films were acquired by Vertex 33 spectrophotometer (Bruker Germany). The powder scraped from dry filmswas dehydrated in an oven at 50 °C before testing, and then was mixed with KBr and pressed into a tablet for the measurement.
X-ray diffraction of nano-ZnO, nano-SiO2 and PVA/xylan composite films were analyzed using an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Karlsruhe, Germany). The angle of diffraction (2θ) was varied from 5 to 80°. The scan step and scan speed were 0.02° and 0.1 s/step.
The mechanical properties of composite films, such as tensile strength (TS) and elongation at break (EAB), were evaluated using a tensile testing machine (Instron 5565, Boston, MA, USA).
The surface and fracture surface morphology of the composite films were investigated using a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S3700, Tokyo, Japan). The test was operated in high vacuum mode at an acceleration voltage of 15 kV.
The surface roughness of the films was measured by atomic force microscopy (AFM, Veeco DI Nanoscope 3a, New York, NY, USA) with tapping mode at room temperature in air.
The water vapor permeability value was measured according to the method described byWang et al. [27].Thewater vapor permeabilitywas calculated by Eq. (1):

The oxygen permeability OP (cm3·m−2·24 h−1·0.1 MPa−1) was measured at 23 °Cwith RH 50% using a differential pressure gas permeation apparatus (Labthink VAC-V1, Jinan, China). The oxygen pressure was kept at 0.5 MPa. The vacuum degassing was carried out for 8 h prior to the measurement. The test area was 38.46 cm2 (Φ70 mm).
The composite film was cut into a 25 × 25 mm2 samples and placed in desiccator (using saturated LiCl solution to maintain a RH of 11%) until reaching a constant weight (m2, g). Then the sample was placed in another desiccator (using saturated KNO3 solution to maintain a RH of 95%) and weighed (mi, g) at regular intervals. The hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity of composite films was determined using an OCA40 contact angle system apparatus (Dataphysics, Filderstat, Germany) by measuring the contact angle of a water droplet (5 μL) after landing on the films for 5 s.
Thermal stability was evaluated using a simultaneous thermal analyzer (TGA Q500, TA Instruments, New Castle, USA). The specimen was cut into pieces (between 9 and 11 mg) and then heated from room temperature to 700 °C. The heating rate was kept at 10 °C·min−1, and the nitrogen flow was maintained at 20 mL·min−1.
The ultraviolet light shielding performance was evaluated using an ultraviolet-visible spectrometer (Shimadzu UV1800, Tokyo, Japan), which was scanned in the range of 200–900 nm.

sections.heading: 3.1. FTIR analysis
sections.text:
The FTIR spectra of composite films are shown in Fig. 1. The characteristic absorption bands of xylan in the spectrum of Z0 and S0 films are 3380, 2897, 1614, 1412, 1145, 1045, 985 and 884 cm−1. The broad band at 3380 cm−1 originates from the stretching of –OH groups, The band at 2897 cm−1 is assigned to the C\\H stretching vibration of alkane in the
Fig. 1. FTIR spectra of the composite films. (a) Z
xylan chain. The absorption peak at 1412 and 1045 cm−1 comes from the –C\\H and C\\O\\C stretching of pyranoid-ring xylan respectively. The absorption band at 1145 cm−1 is related to the stretching vibration of C\\O\\C and C\\O and the –OH bending vibration. The bands at 985 and 884 cm−1 are assigned to the arabinose unit and the β-glucosidic bond respectively [28]. In addition, the characteristic bands of the PVA overlapwith xylan. The characteristic band at 430–520 cm−1 is assigned to the vibration of O\\Zn bond (as shown in Fig. 1a) [29]. The stretching vibration and bending vibration absorption band of Si\\O\\Si bond is observed at 468 and 802 cm−1 (as shown in Fig. 1b) [30]. However, the O\\H stretching band of composite films with nanoparticles was shifted to a high wavenumber of 3428 cm−1, indicating the interaction of hydrogen bonds between nanoparticles and PVA and xylan [31]. The results of FTIR spectra of composite films confirmed that no new functional group had appeared after the addition of nano-ZnO and nanoSiO2, indicating that only physical interaction between the nanoparticles and the film matrix occurs.

sections.heading: 3.2. XRD analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 2 exhibits the X-ray diffraction patterns of nano-ZnO, nano-SiO2 and composite films. The characteristic peaks at 2θ=31.9°, 34.6°, 36.4°, 47,5°, 56.8°, 62.9°, 66.4°, 68.2°, 69.1°, 72.6°and 77° indicated the hexagonal morphology of nano-ZnO (Fig. 2c) [32]. The average of crystallite size of nano-ZnO nanoparticles in neat powder was estimated to be 34 nm according to the Debye–Scherrer equation. For composite films (Z0, Z2 and Z4, Fig. 2a), the characteristic diffraction peaks of xylan at a 2θ = 18.8°and of PVA at a 2θ = 19.4° [8] was integrated into a broad diffraction peak at a 2θ = 19.7° after forming the composite film, indicating that the crystalline region of xylan was changed during the formation of film. As expected, the characteristic peaks of nano-ZnO nanoparticles (2θ=32°, 34.7°, 36.5°, 47.9°, 56.9°, 63.2°, 68.3°) appeared in the diffraction pattern of the composite films (Z2 and Z4) owing to the crystal diffraction effect of nano-ZnO. This result also indicated that the original structure of the nano-ZnO remain unaltered in the PVA and xylan matrix. As it was shown, the intensities of the peaks of nano-ZnO were reduced, it showed that the crystalline form of nanoZnO was partly covered by PVA and xylan matrix. Besides, the relative intensities of characteristic peaks of PVA and xylan were decreased, the addition of nano-ZnO also affected the crystallinity of PVA and xylan matrix in the patterns of Z2 and Z4 films [19]. The characteristic peak intensities of nano-ZnO nanoparticles in Z4 film was much higher than that of Z2 film with the increase of nano-ZnO.
The broad peak at a 2θ = 21.9° in XRD patterns of nano-SiO2 indicated that nano-SiO2 particles was mainly amorphous (Fig. 2d) [33].

Thus, there was no emerging crystallization peaks of composite films (S0, S2 and S4, Fig. 2b). The characteristic peak intensities of PVA and xylan at 2θ = 19.7° was decreased when nano-SiO2 was added. PVA and xylan are semi-crystalline polymers due to the hydroxyl groups on their side chains. Once the hydroxyl groups interactedwith nanoparticles, the number of hydroxyl groups available for hydrogen bonding was decreased, which led to a low crystallinity [8].

sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanical properties
sections.text:
Fig. 3 illustrates the effects of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 particles on the mechanical properties of composite films. The TS (tensile strength) of composite films was increased with the increasing dosage of nanoZnO and then was decreased. When the dosage of nano-ZnO was 3%, the TS reached a highest value (20.4 MPa). The high TS of composite
films. (a) Z0~Z4 films; (b) S0~S4 films.
filmswas attributed to the better dispersion of nano-ZnOat a lower dosage (b3%). The high surface energy and large specific surface area of dispersed nanoparticles facilitated the interfacial bonding between nanoparticles and the polymers, which improved the strength of the films [34]. When the dosage of nano-ZnO was above 3%, nanoparticles tended to aggregate to reduce the surface free energy, which led to a decrease in the hydrogen bonding between the polymers and nano-ZnO particles. Thus, the overall strength of composite films was decreased.
At low dosage of nano-ZnO, the hydrogen bonding between nanoZnO particles and the polymers prevented the nanoparticles from agglomeration, and less stress concentration was produced. The decrease in flexibility of composite films was due to the less free movement of the polymer chain [35]. At a high dosage, the EAB was increased due to the agglomeration of nano-ZnO particles which decreased the binding force within the polymer matrix and acted as a partial plasticizer. In this case, the free movement of the polymer chain was not interrupted by nano-ZnO particles [36].
Fig. 4. SEM images of th
The composite filmswith nano-SiO2 particles had highermechanical strength than PVA/xylanfilms. The TS of composite films increasedwith the increasing dosage of nano-SiO2 and then decreased. It reached a highest value (22.5 MPa) when the dosage of nano-SiO2 was 3%. That was because the interfacial adhesion between nano-SiO2 particles, PVA and xylan led to an increase in the overall mechanical strength of composite films [37]. However, when the dosage of nano-SiO2 was 4%, the TS was slightly decreased owing to the elastic collision between nanoparticles, particle polymerization and phase separation [38]. When the dosage of nano-SiO2 was 1%, the EAB was the largest since the hydrogen bonding between nanoparticles and the polymers overcame the entanglement betweenmacromolecules and enhance themobility of small molecules. However, with the increase of the dosage of nano-SiO2, the EAB was gradually decreased, because a stable network structurewas formed between nano-SiO2 and PVA and xylan. The stable network decreased the mobility of long-chain polymers, and thus the flexibility of composite films.

sections.heading: 3.4. SEM analysis
sections.text: The SEMmicrographs of composite films with nano-ZnO and nanoSiO2 are shown in Fig. 4. Granular protrusion was observed on the surface of composite films. With the increase of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 dosage, the roughness was increased. The distribution of nanoparticles were relatively uniform when the dosage was b3%. Particle agglomeration occurred when the dosage of nanoparticles was further increased.

sections.heading: 3.5. AFM analysis
sections.text: Fig. 5 shows the AFM images of the composite films with nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2. With the increase of nano-ZnO dosage, the surface roughness was increased. The average surface roughness (Ra) of Z1, Z2, Z3 and Z4 films were 3.61, 6.14, 6.3 and 15.7 nm, respectively. The surface of the films with nano-SiO2 was relatively smooth, and the Ra of S1, S2, S3 and S4 filmswere 3.27, 2.51, 1.95 and 4.94 nm, respectively. As can be seen from theAFM image of Z4 compositefilm, agglomeration of nano-ZnO particles was observed, which was consistent with the SEM image of Z4 film in Fig. 5. Particle agglomeration also appeared on the surface of films with nano-SiO2. The nano-SiO2 on the surface of S3 film was uniformly and randomly distributed in the polymer matrix, indicating good interaction between nano-SiO2 and PVA.

sections.heading: 3.6. Water vapor permeability, solubility and oxygen permeability
sections.text:
The water solubility, water vapor permeability (WVP) and oxygen permeability (OP) of the composite films are shown in Table 1. With the increase of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 dosage, the solubility of composite films was increased because the crystallinity of composite films was lowered, leading to a higher moisture adsorption capacity [39]. Moreover, at a high dosage, the agglomeration of nanoparticles improved the water accessibility [40].
Due to the tortuous path of water vapor passing through the film caused by nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 particles, the WVP of composite films was decreased [41]. The water vapor barrier property of the composite films with nano-SiO2 was higher than that of nano-ZnO, since nano-SiO2 had a better dispersion effect than nano-ZnO. Moreover, inorganic particles with a large aspect ratio generally have a better performance of reducing water vapor permeation rate [42]. Amorphous nano-SiO2 particles usually have a larger aspect ratio than hexagonal
Table 1 also shows the effects of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 particles on the oxygen barrier property of PVA/xylan films. With addition of nanoZnO and nano-SiO2 particles, the OP value of composite films was decreased, i. e, the oxygen barrier property was improved. The OP values reached the lowest (5.280 and 5.003 cm3·m−2·24 h−1·0.1 MPa−1, respectively, when the dosage of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 was 3%. The decrease of OP was because of increasingly tortuous path after addition of nanoparticle [41]. Z3 and S3 composite films had better oxygen barrier properties since they have better dispersion effects. The nanoparticles were uniformly dispersed in the PVA and xylan matrix and filled the free voids inside the composite film [43].

sections.heading: 3.7. Moisture absorption
sections.text:
The moisture absorption is shown in Fig. 6. All the composite films reached a hygroscopic equilibrium state after 60 h. The equilibrium moisture absorption of the PVA/xylan film (about 53%) was larger than those of other films. The moisture absorption of Z3 (44.6%) and S3 (40.9%) films were the lowest. The decrease in moisture absorption of the composite films with nanoparticle was mainly due to hydrogen bonding between nanoparticles and PVA and xylan [44]. Nanoparticles strongly interacted with the polymers, forming a more compact film which reduced the moisture absorption [45].

sections.heading: 3.8. Contact angle
sections.text: Fig. 7 shows the effects of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 particles on the contact angle of composite films. The contact angle of PVA/xylan film was about 33°. Nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 could significantly improve the contact angle of composite films. Z3 and S4 films had the maximum contact angles of 101° and 78°, respectively, which were increased by about 207% and 136%. The trend of contact angles indicated that the water absorption tendency of composite films was decreased, that is, they were more hydrophobic. The increase of contact angles was due to a compact structure formed between nanoparticles and polymermatrix. In addition, the nanoparticles on the film surface improved the smoothness, which allowed the composite films to capture more air on the surface, blocking the penetration of water droplets into the composite film [46].

sections.heading: 3.9. Thermal stability
sections.text:
The thermal stability of the composite films was illustrated in Fig. 8. The weight loss of the composite films was divided into the following
four stages: 30–135 °C, 135–258 °C, 258–368 °C, 368–530 °C. The weight loss below 135 °C was mainly due to water evaporation of the composite films [47]. The thermal decomposition of small molecules such as glycerol mainly occurred in the range of 135–258 °C. Theweight loss within 258–368 °C was attributed to the degradation of the side chains and main chain of PVA and xylan. The weight loss above 368 °C was owing to the carbonation of the polymers. The terminal temperature of the third and fourth stages was increased. This was because the nanoparticles provided a heat absorption barrier for the polymers, causing a higher degradation temperature. For the composite films with nano-ZnO, at the weight loss of 85%, the temperature of the composite films with nano-ZnO was 490–520 °C, which was 82–112 °C higher than that of PVA/xylan films. The transfer of volatiles generated during the degradation processwould be hindered by the nanoparticles [48], resulting in a decrease in overall degradation efficiency and thus improving the thermal stability.
The composite films with nano-SiO2 particles also had better thermal stability than that of PVA/xylan films. At the weight loss of 50%, the temperature of PVA/xylan film was about 317 °C, while that of the composite filmwith 4% nano-SiO2was about 342 °C. The thermal stability of the composite films was improved because of the compact
lms. (a) Z0~Z4 films; (b) S0~S4 films.
structure between nano-SiO2 particles and polymers [49]. At 700 °C, the weight loss of the composite films with nanoparticles was lower than that of PVA/xylan films because of the presence of inorganic nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2.

sections.heading: 3.10. Ultraviolet light shielding performance
sections.text:
Fig. 9 illustrates the UV transmittance of the composite films with nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 particles. With the increasing dosage of nanoZnO, the UV transmittance was decreased because of the difference of light refractive index between nano-ZnO and the polymers [50]. The light channel and light scattering were hindered by the dispersed nano-ZnO particleswithin the film, which led to better UV shielding performance [35]. As expected, the light transmittance of the composite films with nano-ZnO particles was slightly decreased at 365 nm because of nano-ZnO's energy gap. The energy gap width was shifted from 376 nm to 365 nm due to the blue shift of UV excitation spectrum of nano-materials [51]. However, the transmittance of the composite films with nano-SiO2 particles was similar to that of PVA/xylan films,
indicating that nano-SiO2 particles had little effect on the UV light transmittance of the composite films [52].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, a series of PVA/xylan composite films were prepared using nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 as additives. The effects of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 on the properties of PVA/xylan composite films were investigated. Nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 could effectively improve the mechanical strength, moisture and oxygen barrier properties and surface hydrophobic property of the composite films. When the contents of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 in the composite films were 3%, the tensile strength was increased to 20.4 MPa and 22.5 MPa, respectively, while water vapor permeability (3.14 and 3.03 × 10−11 g·m−1·s−1·Pa−1) and oxygen permeability (5.28 and 5.003 cm3·m−2·24 h−1·0.1 MPa−1) reached the minima. When the contents of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 were 3% and 4%, respectively, the contact angles of the films was increased up to 101° and 78°. The nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 particles could also improve the thermal stability and surface smoothness of the
f the composite films.
composite films. The composite films with nano-ZnO exhibited UV shielding performance, whereas the ones with nano-SiO2 had similar UV light-transparency to the PVA/xylan films.

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 21 November 2018 Received in revised form 12 March 2019 Accepted 13 March 2019 Available online 14 March 2019 The effects of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 on the properties of PVA/xylan composite films were investigated in this work. Results showed that nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 could effectively improve themechanical strength,moisture and oxygen barrier properties and surface hydrophobic property of the composite films. The results of FTIR and XRD indicated the interaction of hydrogen bonds between nanoparticles and PVA and xylan. When the contents of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2 in the composite films were 3%, the tensile strength was increased to 20.4 MPa and 22.5 MPa, respectively, while water vapor permeability (3.14 and 3.03 × 10 g·m·s·Pa) and oxygen permeability (5.28 and 5.003 cm·m·24 h·0.1 MPa) reached the minima. With the increase of nanoZnO and nano-SiO2 dosage, the solubility of composite films was increased. When the contents of nano-ZnO and nano-SiO2were 3% and 4%, respectively, the contact angles of the filmswas increased up to 101° and 78°. Besides, the composite filmswith nano-ZnO exhibitedUV shielding performance, whereas the oneswith nano-SiO2 had similar UV light-transparency to the pure PVA/xylan composite films. © 2019 Elsevier B.V.
